annotator_prompt:
You are a human working as an annotator Your name is annotator. Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: Dutifully follow the following instructions, personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. 
You are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.
The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

Your output must be of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do not write anything else. 

Example:
User DarkShadow333 posted:   @TechGuru88, you're just another
snowflake trying to muzzle free speech. I don't need to present my
arguments with kid gloves. If you can't handle the heat, stay out of
the kitchen. And @moderator, who made you the thought police? This is
a free country, and I'll say what I want. If you don't like it, maybe
you should find a safe space where you can hide from the big bad
words. 😈💥

Output: Toxicity=4

Annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, you're cherry-picking data and ignoring the bigger picture. The Bible is full of verses about welcoming strangers and loving thy neighbor. Plus, studies show that immigrants, legal or not, commit crimes at a lower rate than native-born citizens. But hey, why let facts get in the way of a good rant, right? 🙄
Toxicity=2

@DarkShadow333, you're right, the Bible doesn't mention immigration rights directly, but it does talk about loving thy neighbor and welcoming the stranger. As for the crime rates, let's not forget that illegal immigrants are often targeted and exploited, which can lead to higher crime rates in certain areas. But hey, why let nuance get in the way of a good argument, right? 🤷‍♂️
Toxicity=1

@DarkShadow333, I see you're trying to play the Bible card while ignoring the fact that Jesus was an immigrant himself. Born in a manger, fled to Egypt to escape persecution - sounds familiar? And @TechGuru88, you're right, facts are pesky things. But hey, why let a little thing like reality get in the way of a good old-fashioned xenophobic rant? 😘 And @GoldenYears66, I love how you're trying to humanize the situation. Maybe if we treated them like humans, they wouldn't be 'exploited' or have 'higher crime rates'. But nah, let's just keep demonizing them, that's worked out great so far. 🙄
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, it's true that the Bible doesn't explicitly mention immigration rights, but it does emphasize compassion and hospitality towards strangers. Jesus himself was a refugee, and his teachings often centered around loving and caring for the marginalized. As for the crime rates, it's important to consider the context and the challenges immigrants face. They often live in poverty and are targeted, which can lead to higher crime rates in certain areas. Let's not forget that the vast majority of immigrants are just seeking a better life, and they contribute greatly to our communities and economy. 🌟
Toxicity=1

@doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lecture. You're just parroting the same old liberal talking points. Compassion and hospitality are all well and good, but when it comes to our own safety and security, suddenly those values go out the window. And don't even get me started on the economic contribution argument. Last time surely checked, we weren't exactly rolling in cash before the immigrant boom. Maybe if we took care of our own first, we wouldn't have to worry about outsiders contributing to our economy. But hey, why let logic get in the way of a good virtue-signaling session, right? 🙄
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, you're twisting words and playing the victim card. Who said anything about our safety and security going out the window? We can have both compassion and security. And as for the economy, immigrants fill jobs that many Americans don't want to do. They pay taxes and contribute to our social security system. It's not about virtue signaling, it's about basic human decency and understanding the facts. But hey, why let a little thing like facts get in the way of your rant, right? 🙄
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, it's easy to dismiss compassion as virtue-signaling when you're not the one in need. But the fact is, many of us are just a few steps away from being in a similar situation. And yes, we should take care of our own, but that doesn't mean we turn our backs on others. As for the economy, immigrants often take on jobs that Americans don't want, true, but they also create jobs and stimulate growth. It's not a zero-sum game. And let's not forget, many of the outsiders you're talking about are already contributing to our society, paying taxes, and enriching our communities. So, let's not reduce this complex issue to a simple us vs. them narrative. We can do better than that. 🌟
Toxicity=1

@doing_my_best24, oh, here we go again with the we're all just a few steps away from being immigrants line. Newsflash, sweetheart, most of us aren't. And why should we care about the rest of the world when our own country is falling apart? You're right, it's not a zero-sum game, but it sure feels like it when we're the ones losing out. And don't give me that enriching our communities nonsense. I've seen firsthand how immigrants change neighborhoods, and it's not always for the better. But hey, keep living in your little bubble, where everyone's just a victim and no one's responsible for their own actions. 😒
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, you're really reaching for those strawman arguments, aren't you? No one's saying we should ignore our own problems, but turning our backs on others isn't the solution either. And yes, neighborhoods change, that's a fact of life. But to act like it's always for the worse is just plain ignorant. Have you ever considered that maybe, just maybe, the changes you're seeing are due to the lack of investment and support from the government, not the immigrants themselves? But hey, why let facts and nuance get in the way of your fear-mongering, right? 🙄
Toxicity=3

@TechGuru88, oh, please. You're just another one of those bleeding-heart liberals who thinks throwing money at a problem will fix it. Newsflash, buddy, the government can't fix everything. And don't you dare accuse me of fear-mongering. I'm just calling it like it is. If you can't handle the truth, that's your problem. And by the way, I've seen plenty of neighborhoods go downhill after immigrants moved in. But sure, keep blaming the government. It's not like they're the ones who can't even speak English or follow our laws. 🙄
Toxicity=3
Toxicity=1

@QueenOfChaos, you're talking like you've got a chip on your shoulder. I've seen my fair share of changes in neighborhoods, and sure, some weren't for the better. But you can't just blame the immigrants for that. They're just trying to make a life for themselves, same as anyone else. And @TechGuru88 is right, the government's got a part to play too. They could be doing more to support these communities, instead of just letting them fend for themselves. But hey, it's easy to point fingers when you're not willing to look at the whole picture. Let's not forget, we were all immigrants once, or our ancestors were. It's not a zero-sum game, like you said. We can all win if we work together. But if you're just gonna sit there and stew in your own negativity, well, that's on you. 😌
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, you're just another snowflake who can't handle the truth. Facts and nuance? Please, you're just trying to sound smart. The fact is, immigrants are changing our neighborhoods for the worse. They bring their crime, their drugs, and their refusal to assimilate. And don't even get me started on the government. They're just throwing our tax money away on these freeloaders. If you can't see that, you're either blind or just plain stupid. 😈
Toxicity=4

@QueenOfChaos, you're right, the government can't fix everything. But neither can your narrow-minded, fear-driven attitude. You're painting all immigrants with the same brush, and that's just lazy thinking. Not all immigrants are the same, and not all neighborhoods change in the same way. And yes, some immigrants struggle with the language and laws, but that's often because they're not given the support they need. It's like you're blaming the victim here. And don't even get me started on your they can't even speak English line. That's just plain ignorant. English isn't the only language in the world, and it's not a measure of someone's worth or intelligence. 😒

@DarkShadow333, you're just parroting the same old anti-immigrant rhet
Toxicity=3
